We know that the optimal solution of the LP relaxation of an ILP is a lower bound of the optimal solution of the ILP. We also know that the objective function value of any dual solution is at most the optimal solution of the primal LP. Therefore, we have: \text {obj(dual)} \leq \text {OPT(LP relaxation)} \leq \text {OPT(ILP)}
Given an integral primal solution P , the goal is to find a feasible dual solution D such that: \text {obj(P)} \leq c \cdot \text {obj(D)} That is, obj(P) and obj(D) differ by c as shown in this figure
